item.title: 【Music Videos】U2 - One [4K Remaster | HEVC 10-bit | PCM 24-bit | DD+ Dolby Atmos]
item.description:
Genre: Rock
Style: Pop Rock
Year: 1992
Video Source: YouTube, Remaster, 2160p (no better source available)
Audio Source: Qobuz (Hi-Res) & Apple Music, with help of SonMaxime

"One" is a song by Irish rock band U2. It is the third track from their seventh album, Achtung Baby (1991), and it was released as the record's third single on 24 February 1992. During the album's recording sessions at Hansa Studios in Berlin, conflict arose between the band members over the direction of U2's sound and the quality of their material. Tensions almost prompted the band to break up until they achieved a breakthrough with the improvisation of "One"; the song was written after the band members were inspired by a chord progression that guitarist the Edge was playing in the studio. The lyrics, written by lead singer Bono, were inspired by the band members' fractured relationships and the German reunification. Although the lyrics ostensibly describe "disunity", they have been interpreted in other ways.

"One" was released as a benefit single, with proceeds going towards AIDS research. The song topped the Irish Singles Charts, the Canadian RPM Top Singles chart and the US Billboard Album Rock Tracks and Modern Rock Tracks charts. It also peaked at number three in New Zealand, number four in Australia, number seven on the UK Singles Chart and number ten on the Billboard Hot 100.

The song was acclaimed by critics upon its release, and it has since been featured in polls of the greatest songs of all time. U2 has performed "One" at most of their tour concerts since the song's live debut in 1992, and it has appeared in many of the band's concert films. In a live setting, "One" is often used by the group to promote human rights or social justice causes, and the song lends its namesake to Bono's charitable organisation, the ONE Campaign. U2 re-recorded the song as part of a duet with R&B recording artist Mary J. Blige on her 2005 album The Breakthrough, and again for the band's 2023 album Songs of Surrender (2023).

Three music videos were created for "One". The video of this release is the third one, directed by Rattle and Hum director Phil Joanou and was primarily filmed in early March 1992 at Nell's, a Manhattan nightclub while the band were in the US for their Zoo TV tour. The video was filmed in an attempt to appeal to a broader audience and it depicts Bono sitting at a table smoking a cheroot and drinking beer, interspersed with footage of the band performing in concert. While Bono was filmed, the rest of the band, along with models and transgender women, attended a party in the basement, awaiting their turns to be filmed. However, they were never called to the set and by 3 a.m., they realised that the video was to focus on Bono.

Release Info
The video track is the 4K Remaster, downloaded from YouTube, del. bars and encoded to HEVC 10-bit.
The PCM track is downloaded from Qobuz (Hi-Res, 24-bit 44.1 kHz) and synced with Adobe Audition.
The Atmos track is downloaded from Apple Music and synced by muxing (delay, no quality loss).
The timed lyrics are synced and edited. Enable the subtitles to see the lyrics.

Note: The Atmos track is taken from the remastered Atmos release of Achtung Baby, you can download the album here.
